video.title: Deploy 12 apps to AWS, Azure, & Google Cloud
video.description:
Learn how to deploy 12 different apps to 3 different cloud services. 

✏️ This course was created by Scalable Scripts. Check out their channel: https://www.youtube.com/c/ScalableScripts

⌨️ (0:00:00) Intro
⌨️ (0:00:37) Dockerize a React app
⌨️ (0:08:57) Dockerize a NodeJS app
⌨️ (0:13:40) Dockerize a VueJS app
⌨️ (0:20:00) Dockerize a NestJS app
⌨️ (0:26:26) Dockerize an Angular app
⌨️ (0:35:00) Dockerize a Golang app
⌨️ (0:41:23) Dockerize a Svelte app
⌨️ (0:47:27) Dockerize a Django app
⌨️ (0:52:12) Dockerize a Laravel app
⌨️ (0:56:32) Dockerize a .NET Core app
⌨️ (1:03:41) Dockerize a Spring Boot app with Kotlin
⌨️ (1:11:20) Dockerize a Deno app
⌨️ (1:16:33) Deploy a Container to AWS
⌨️ (1:25:22) Deploy a Container to Azure
⌨️ (1:32:32) Deploy a Container to Google Cloud

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Wong Voon jinq
👾 hexploitation
👾 Katia Moran
👾 BlckPhantom
👾 Nick Raker
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster
👾 Treehouse
👾 AppWrite

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

Create app
Create docker file
Add code to docker file

topLevelComment.author: romi_devx
topLevelComment.text: Thank you for this great tutorial, but i have a question ? At 4:15,  i didn´t understand why do you need "nginx" to run react inside a container ?

replies.author: Ehsan Ahmed
replies.text:
​@romi_devx even I thought you're supposed to do that the first time I tried this. You were probably manually running the container via docker, with some shell attached using -it, and in that case it's OK. 

But usually you would run containers via Kubernetes, or wherever else, and then running in nginx is important for the reasons I mentioned in my previous comment

replies.author: romi_devx
replies.text: @Ehsan Ahmed i thought, if you include the comand CMD ["npm", "start"], in the end of the "dockerfile", it would run ok ..well at least for me it did

replies.author: Ehsan Ahmed
replies.text:
That's because containers need to have a running process in them to 'stay alive'. So if you just build the react app and run the container, you'd most likely get a CRASHLOOPBACKOFF error (if you're running it in K8s for example) which would mean the container inside the pod keeps crashing. 
An nginx container can be understood as a server that's always running, which means there's always a running process, so that keeps the pod/container alive. 
So you put the react app inside the nginx container because the react app can't 'stay alive' on it's own and needs something else to keep it alive, which is usally an nginx container. 
Someone can correct me if I'm wrong about anything, as I'm also learning these technologies 🙂

This medium blog post exactly answers your question: https://tiangolo.medium.com/react-in-docker-with-nginx-built-with-multi-stage-docker-builds-including-testing-8cc49d6ec305

topLevelComment.author: Geek With A Camera
topLevelComment.text: He is wrongly referring to image as container while running docker build. "docker build -t app" command creates an "image" named "app" not "container". Container is created from the image only when you run command "docker run". Image is like a blueprint and container a running instance of the image. Nonetheless great video!

topLevelComment.author: Mr Lloyd
topLevelComment.text:
Pardon me if my question is obvious:

But it seems(at least for Go and React, I'm not experienced with the other languages) that he copies the source code from the host into a container and then builds that inside the container, is this how it's supposed to be done? I personally build react and Go apps on my local machine then copy the binary into the container but I'm a beginner so please advise

replies.author: A Casual Gamer
replies.text: fireship has a great explanation for this "docker in 100 seconds" https://youtu.be/Gjnup-PuquQ

replies.author: A Casual Gamer
replies.text: @Mr Lloyd glad i could help ^_^

replies.author: Mr Lloyd
replies.text: @A Casual Gamer thanks mate! that makes sense!

replies.author: A Casual Gamer
replies.text:
i believe building it in the container is how it should be done. Because the environment will always be the same, 
you avoid the "it works on my machine" issue where other people(or you building on a different pc/server) trying to build your software may have issues due to different OS/node or go version/missing libraries/Missing tools to build certain node modules etc. Of course thats not the only advantage but thats the first thing came to mind :p
(PS: im also a newbie in docker)
